notes:
1. Definition

A cyclic process is a sequence of thermodynamic processes that starts and ends in the same state. At the conclusion of a cycle, all the properties of the system (such as temperature, pressure, volume, and internal energy) have the same values they had at the beginning.

2. First Law for a Cycle

The change in any state property over a full cycle is zero. Since internal energy ($U$) is a state property, its net change over one cycle is zero.

$$\Delta U_{cycle} = 0$$

Applying the First Law of Thermodynamics, $\Delta U = Q - W$, to a full cycle:

$$0 = Q_{net} - W_{net}$$ $$Q_{net} = W_{net}$$

This means that for a cyclic process, the net heat transferred to the system is equal to the net work done by the system.

$Q_{net} = Q_{in} - Q_{out}$ and $W_{net} = W_{out} - W_{in}$.

3. P-V Diagram

A cyclic process is represented by a closed loop on a P-V diagram. The net work done during the cycle is equal to the area enclosed by the loop.

  • If the loop is traversed in a clockwise direction, the net work is positive ($W_{net} > 0$), representing a heat engine.
  • If the loop is traversed in a counter-clockwise direction, the net work is negative ($W_{net} < 0$), representing a refrigerator or heat pump.

solvedExamples.question: What is the net change in internal energy for any system that undergoes a cyclic process?

options.text: Equal to the net heat transfer

solvedExamples.explanation: Internal energy is a state property, meaning it only depends on the current state of the system, not how it got there. Since a cyclic process starts and ends in the same state, the net change in internal energy must be zero.

solvedExamples.question: A heat engine in a cyclic process absorbs 1000 J of heat from a hot reservoir and rejects 600 J of heat to a cold reservoir. How much net work does the engine perform?
solvedExamples.explanation: For a cyclic process, the net work done is equal to the net heat transfer: $W_{net} = Q_{net}$. The net heat transfer is the heat absorbed minus the heat rejected: $Q_{net} = Q_{in} - Q_{out} = 1000 \text{ J} - 600 \text{ J} = 400 \text{ J}$. Therefore, $W_{net} = 400 \text{ J}$.
